div.head: TO THE RIGHT WORSHIPFVL Sr CONIER CLIFFORD KNIGHT. health and felicitie.
div.p:
VLYSSES (Right worshipfull) hauing spent some time in the Court of Aeolus, where he was friendly entertained, desired at length to be dismissed: his sute was granted, and he sent away in Princely manner, with all the windes tied vp in a bottle, to be commaunded as he thought best. He was not past a dayes iourney or two from the shore, but he went to wracke thorough the misdealing of those, to
whose safe conduct he had committed himselfe, and by the winds was driuen backe againe to the coast of Aeolia. His weather beaten men, and himselfe being refreshed as time & place then serued, he set forward to Aeolus his Court, hoping to find such entertainment as he found before. Not daring sodainly to enter in, he rested himselfe at the Porter his lodge, where he heard these words:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

It may be they moued his patience a little, because they touched his former estate, yet hauing better conceite of others in that place he let them passe, and preased forward to the presence of the King, sitting not farre off with his Nobilitie about him, to whom he spake
thus in humble manner:

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And that his request might the better preuaile, he added his reason, (For it is not likely though his estate were bad, that he would craue any thing more then reason.) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . But he was so farre off from finding his expected reliefe, that he was commaunded to get him thence with these hot wordes to his cold comfort:

Such as Vlysses his departure was from the Iland Aeolia, such was mine from London Northward; such as his entertainement was at his returne, such was mine cōming thither againe. For miscarying in that voyage besides mine expectation
(I would say my desert were it not presumption) I found that of Horace to be true:

Some said they could not, some durst not for feare, and some answered they would not helpe to repaire that losse, which the vnkind Northerne blast had inforced me to. VVhat should I do, or what other thing could I doe in this case, but that which Vlysses had donne before? 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . I suffered all, and bare it out, not lying still as a man carelesse, but knowing mine head and handes (vnder God) to be my best friends, I set them to their old occupation againe, teaching the Mathematicall arts, and penning, or translating such books as I thought most conuenient for
that purpose, of the which this booke is some little part. And for so much (Right worshipfull) as I intended therein not onely your pleasure, but your profit especially among the rest, I am bold to make that intent knowne in dedicating it vnto your VVorship, & crauing your fauorable acceptance therof, which if it please you to afford, you shall inuite me to a farther worke, and bind me not to be vnthankfull for your friendly fauour.

closer.signed: Your worships to commaund, THOMAS HOOD.
